Chapter 44 Amortization of Premium or Discount

Laura buys two bonds at time \(0\).
Bond \(X\) is a \(1000\) par value \(14\) year bond with \(10\%\) annual coupons. It is bought at a price to yield an annual effective rate of \(8\%\).
Bond \(Y\) is a \(14\) year par value bond with \(6.75\%\) annual coupons and a face amount of \(F\).
Laura pays \(P\) for the bond to yield an annual effective rate of \(8\%\). During year \(6\) the writedown in premium (principal adjustment) on bond \(X\) is equal to the writeup in discount (principal adjustment) on bond \(Y\). Calculate \(P\).
Answer
Bond \(X\)

\(F = 1000\)
\(r = 10\%\) p.a.
\(i = 8\%\) p.a.
\(n = 14\) years

Bond \(Y\)

\(r = 6.75\%\) p.a.
\(i = 8\%\) p.a.
\(n = 14\) years

Assume F = C
Calculating \(P_6\) for Bond \(X\) \[\begin{align*}
P_t &= C\left(\frac{Fr}{C}-i\right)v^{n-t+1} \\
P_{6(X)} &= 1000\left(\frac{1000 \cdot 10\%}{1000}-8\%\right)(1+8\%)^{-14+6-1}
\end{align*}\]
Calculating \(P_6\) for Bond \(Y\) \[\begin{align*}
P_t &= C\left(\frac{Fr}{C}-i\right)v^{n-t+1} \\
P_{6(Y)} &= F\left(\frac{F \cdot 6.75\%}{F}-8\%\right)(1+8\%)^{-14+6-1}
\end{align*}\]
\[\begin{align*}
P_{6(X)} & = P_{6(Y)} \\
1000\left(\frac{1000 \cdot 10\%}{1000}-8\%\right)(1+8\%)^{-14+6-1} & = F\left(\frac{F \cdot 6.75\%}{F}-8\%\right)(1+8\%)^{-14+6-1} \\
1000\left(10\%-8\%\right) & = F\left(6.75\%-8\%\right) \\
F = 1600
\end{align*}\]
Thus,
\[\begin{align*}
P &= Fr\left(\frac{1-(1+i)^{-n}}{i}\right) + F(1+i)^{-n} \\
&= 1435.11
\end{align*}\]

Let \(I := [a,b]\) and let \(f : I \to \mathbb{R}\) be a continuous function on \(I\) such that for each \(x\) in \(I\) there exist \(y\) in \(I\) such that \(|f(y)| \leq \frac{1}{2}|f(x)|\). Prove there exist a point \(c\) in \(I\) such that \(f(c) = 0\)
Answer
It will be shown that there exist a point \(c\) in \(I\) such that \(f(c) = 0\)
Because for any \(x \in I\) the inequality \(|f(y)| \leq \frac{1}{2}|f(x)|\) is true, then we have the following
\[\begin{align*}
    |f(y_0)| & \leq \frac{1}{2}|f(x)| \\
    |f(y_1)| & \leq \frac{1}{2}|f(y_0)|  \leq \frac{1}{2^2}|f(x)|\\
    .\\
    .\\
    .\\
    |f(y_n)| & \leq \frac{1}{2}|f(y_{n-1})| \leq \frac{1}{2^n+1}|f(x)|
\end{align*}\]
Thus we can construct a sequence \(|y| = (|f(y_n)|)\) which has a property that it is monotonically decreasing sequence. By definition of absolute value, infimum of \(\{|y_n| : n \in \mathbb{N}\}\) is equal to 0. Thus from Monotone Convergence Theorem \(\lim |f(y_n)| = 0\). From property of continuity function, \(|f|\) also continuous because \(f\) continuous thus \(|f(c)| = 0\) which implies \(f(c) = 0\)
\(\therefore \exists c \in I \ni f(c) = 0\)

Let \(I := [a,b]\) and let \(f : I \to \mathbb{R}\) be a continuous function such that \(f(x) > 0\) for each \(x\) in \(I\). Prove that there exist a number \(\alpha > 0\) such that \(f(x) \geq \alpha\) for all \(x \in I\)
Answer
It will be proven that \(\exists\alpha>0 \ni f(x) \geq \alpha \; \forall x \in I\)
Because \(I\) is closed bounded interval and \(f\) continuous on \(I\), by boundedness theorem it follows that \(f\) is bounded on \(I\) thus \(\exists M > 0 \ni |f(x)| < M \;  \forall x \in I\). Because \(f(x) > 0 \; \forall x \in I\), then \(0 < f(x) < M \; \forall x \in I\). Now let \(f(I) := \{f(x) : x \in I\}\). Because 0 is lower bound, by completeness property \(f(I)\) must have an infimum. Let \(\alpha = \inf f(I)\), thus by definition of infimum \(\alpha \leq c \; \forall c \in f(I)\) which implies \(\alpha \leq f(x) \; \forall x \in I\)
\(\therefore \; \exists\alpha>0 \ni f(x) \geq \alpha \; \forall x \in I\)

Let \(a < b < c\). Suppose that \(f\) is continuous on \([a, b]\), that \(g\) is continuous on \([b, c]\), and that \(f(b) = g(b)\). Define \(h\) on \([a,c]\) by \(h(x) := f(x)\) for \(x \in [a, b]\) and \(h(x) = := g(x)\) for \(x \in [b,c]\). Prove that \(h\) is continuous on \([a, c]\)
Answer
Preliminary Analysis
Notice that \(h(x) = \begin{cases}
    f(x) & x \in [a,b] \\
    g(x) & x \in [b,c]
\end{cases}\).
Thus for \([a,b]\), \(h\) continuous because \(f\) continuous, and for \([b,c]\), \(h\) continuous because \(g\) continuous. Also, because \(f(b) = g(b)\), then it follows that \(h(b) = f(b) = g(b)\) which implies that \(h\) continuous at \(x = b\). Therefore \(h\) continuous on \([a,c]\) \
Formal Proof
\(h\) continuous on \([a,c]\) because \(h\) continuous on \([a,b]\) and \([b,c]\)

Let \(I := [a,b]\) and let \(f : I \to \mathbb{R}\) and \(g : I \to \mathbb{R}\) be a continuous function on \(I\). Show that the set \(E := \{x \in I : f(x) = g(x)\}\) has the property that if \((x_n) \subseteq E\) and \(x_n \to x_0\), then \(x_0 \in E\)
Answer
It will be shown that if \((x_n) \subseteq E\) and \(x_n \to x_0\), then \(x_0 \in E\)
Because \((x_n) \subseteq E\), then it follows that \(f(x_n) = g(x_n)\). Because \(f\) and \(g\) a continuous function on \(I\), then by sequential criteria it follows that if \(x_0 \in I\) implies \(f(x_n) \to f(x_0)\) and \(g(x_n) \to g(x_0)\). Because \(f(x_n) = g(x_n)\), then by sequential limit property \(f(x_0)\) must equal to \(g(x_0)\) which means \(x_0 \in E\)
\(\therefore\) if \((x_n) \subseteq E\) and \(x_n \to x_0\), then \(x_0 \in E\)

Show that every polynomial of odd degree with real coefficients has at least one real root \
Answer
It will be shown that every polynomial of odd degree with real coefficients has at least one real root
Let \(p:I \to \mathbb{R}\) be an odd degree polynomial. It can be shown that \(p\) is continuous on any real-valued interval. If n is odd, then \(x^n \leq 0 \; \forall x \leq 0\). Thus we can choose \(a \in I\) and \(a \leq 0\) such that \(p(a) < 0\) for big enough \(a\). With similiar reasoning, we can choose \(b \in I\) and \(b \geq 0\) such that \(p(b) > 0\). Thus \(p(a) < 0 < p(b)\), which by Intermediate Value Theorem guaranteed the existence of \(c \in I \ni f(c) = 0\)

Show that the polynomial \(p(x) := x^4 + 7x^3 - 9\) has at least two real roots. Use a calculator to locate these roots to within two decimal places
Answer
It will be shown that \(p(x) := x^4 + 7x^3 - 9\) has at least two real roots
Notice that \(p\) is continuous on any \(I \subseteq \mathbb{R}\) because \(\forall c \in \mathbb{R}, \; p(c) = \displaystyle{\lim_{x \to c}} \; p(x)\). Let \(a = 0\), then \(p(a) = -9\) which mean \(a\) is not root of \(p\)
If \(p(\alpha) \geq 0\), then \[\begin{align}
    \alpha^4 + 7\alpha^3 - 9 \geq 0
\end{align}\]
Because \(c^4 \geq 0 \; \forall c \in \mathbb{R}\), then the above equation always hold if \(7\alpha^3 \geq 9\) which have a real solution \(\alpha \geq \sqrt[3]{\frac{9}{7}}\). Thus if we let \(I_1 := [a, b_1]\) where \(b_1 = \sqrt[3]{\frac{9}{7}}\), then \(p(a_1) < 0\) and \(p(b_1) > 0\). Therefore by Location of Root Theorem \(\exists c_1 \in I_1 \ni p(c_1) = 0\)
Notice that ^4 + 7^3 - 9 also true if \(\alpha = -10\) because \((-10)^4 + 7(-10)^3 - 9 = 10000 - 7000 - 9 > 0\), thus if we let \(I_2 := [a, b_2]\) where \(b_2 = -10\), then by Location of Root Theorem \(\exists c_2 \in I_2 \ni p(c_2) = 0\)
\(\therefore p(x)\) has at least 2 real roots because there are 2 closed intervals \(I_1\) and \(I_2\) which have \(c_1 \in I_!\) and \(c_2 \in I2\) where \(c_1 \neq c_2\) resulting in \(p(c_1) = 0 = p(c_2)\)

Let \(f\) be continuous on the interval [0, 1] to \(\mathbb{R}\) and such that \(f(0) = f(1)\). Prove that there exists a point \(c\) in \([0, \frac{1}{2}]\) such that \(f(c) = f(c + \frac{1}{2})\)
Answer
It will be shown that \(\exists c \in [0, \frac{1}{2}] \ni f(c) = f(c + \frac{1}{2})\)
Let \(g\) be a function defined as \(g(x) := f(x) - f(x + \frac{1}{2})\). We have \[g(0) = f(0) - f(\frac{1}{2})\] \[g(\frac{1}{2}) = f(\frac{1}{2}) - f(1)\]
By adding the two equation then \(g(0) + g(\frac{1}{2}) = 0\) thus \(g(0) = -g(\frac{1}{2})\)
Thus by Intermediate Value Theorem, \(g(c) = 0\) must exist if \(c \in [0, \frac{1}{2}]\). Therefore \(f(c) - f(c + \frac{1}{2}) = 0\) or \(f(c) = f(c+\frac{1}{2})\)

An investor purchases a \(26\)-week T-bill with face value of \(\$10,000\) and with a discount yield of \(d\) for \(\$9,600\).

Find \(d\).
Even though T-bills are not usually quoted on an annual effective yield basis, the annual effective yield can still be determined. Find the annual effective rate of interest of this investment, assuming the investment period is exactly half a year.

Answer

\(F = 10000\)
\(P = 9600\)
\(n = 26\) week

Let \(d'\) is the weekly effective disount yield rate, thus
\[\begin{align*}
P &= F(1-d')^n\\

9600 &=  1000(1-d')^{26}\\

d' &= 0.00156884

\end{align*}\]
We must find the annual effective discount yield rate as \(d\), and the annual effective rate of interest as \(i\)
\[\begin{align*}
(1-d')^26 &= (1-d)^{0.5}\\
d &= 0.0783998
\end{align*}\]
\[\begin{align*}
(1-d')^26 &= (1+i)^{-0.5}\\
i &=0.0850692
\end{align*}\]
